t: Isaiah 13
Proclamation Against Babylon
The*p burden against Babylon which Isaiah the son of Amoz saw.
“Lift*pn up a banner on the high mountain, Raise*ld your voice to them; Wave*ld your hand, that they may enter the gates of the nobles.
I*ld have commanded My sanctified ones; I*ld have also called My mighty ones for My anger— Those*ld who rejoice in My exaltation.”
The*ln noise of a multitude in the mountains, Like*ld that of many people! A*ld tumultuous noise of the kingdoms of nations gathered together! The*ld Lord*s of hosts musters The*ld army for battle.
They*ld come from a far country, From*ld the end of heaven— The*ld Lord*s and His weapons of indignation, To*ld destroy the whole land.
Wail,*ln for the day of the Lord*s is*i at hand! It*ld will come as destruction from the Almighty.
Therefore*ld all hands will be limp, Every*ld man’s heart will melt,

And*ld they will be afraid. Pangs*ld and sorrows will take hold of them;*i They*ld will be in pain as a woman in childbirth; They*ld will be amazed at one another; Their*ld faces will*i be*i like*i flames.
Behold,*ln the day of the Lord*s comes, Cruel,*ld with both wrath and fierce anger, To*ld lay the land desolate; And*ld He will destroy its sinners from it.
For*ld the stars of heaven and their constellations Will*ld not give their light; The*ld sun will be darkened in its going forth, And*ld the moon will not cause its light to shine.
“I*ln will punish the world for its*i evil, And*ld the wicked for their iniquity; I*ld will halt the arrogance of the proud, And*ld will lay low the haughtiness of the terrible.
I*ld will make a mortal more rare than fine gold, A*ld man more than the golden wedge of Ophir.
Therefore*ld I will shake the heavens, And*ld the earth will move out of her place, In*ld the wrath of the Lord*s of hosts And*ld in the day of His fierce anger.
It*ld shall be as the hunted gazelle, And*ld as a sheep that no man takes up; Every*ld man will turn to his own people, And*ld everyone will flee to his own land.
Everyone*ld who is found will be thrust through, And*ld everyone who is captured will fall by the sword.
Their*ld children also will be dashed to pieces before their eyes; Their*ld houses will be plundered And*ld their wives ravished.
“Behold,*ln I will stir up the Medes against them, Who*ld will not regard silver; And*ld as*i for*i gold, they will not delight in it.
Also*ld their*i bows will dash the young men to pieces, And*ld they will have no pity on the fruit of the womb; Their*ld eye will not spare children.
And*ld Babylon, the glory of kingdoms, The*ld beauty of the Chaldeans’ pride, Will*ld be as when God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah.
It*ld will never be inhabited, Nor*ld will it be settled from generation to generation; Nor*ld will the Arabian pitch tents there, Nor*ld will the shepherds make their sheepfolds there.
But*ld wild beasts of the desert will lie there, And*ld their houses will be full of owls; Ostriches*ld will dwell there, And*ld wild goats will caper there.
The*ld hyenas will howl in their citadels, And*ld jackals in their pleasant palaces. Her*ld time is*i near to come, And*ld her days will not be prolonged.”
